text: The Song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth;
For thy love is better than wine.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
I am black, but comely,
Oh ye daughters of Jerusalem,
As the tents of Kedar,
As the curtains of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth,
Where thou feedest thy flock,
Where thou makest it to rest at noon:
For why should I be as one that is veiled
Beside the flocks of thy companions?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou know not, O thou fairest among women,
Go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock,
And feed thy kids beside the shepherds’ tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have compared thee, O my love,
To a steed in Pharaoh’s chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy cheeks are comely with plaits of hair,
Thy neck with strings of jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We will make thee plaits of gold
With studs of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While the king sat at his table,
My spikenard sent forth its fragrance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is unto me as a bundle of myrrh,
That lieth betwixt my breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is unto me as a cluster of henna-flowers
In the vineyards of En-gedi.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant:
Also our couch is green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The beams of our house are cedars,
And our rafters are firs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a rose of Sharon,
A lily of the valleys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a lily among thorns,
So is my love among the daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the apple-tree among the trees of the wood,
So is my beloved among the sons.
I sat down under his shadow with great delight,
And his fruit was sweet to my taste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought me to the banqueting-house,
And his banner over me was love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stay ye me with raisins, refresh me with apples;
For I am sick from love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left hand is under my head,
And his right hand doth embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
By the roes, or by the hinds of the field,
That ye stir not up, nor awake my love,
Until he please.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The voice of my beloved! behold, he cometh,
Leaping upon the mountains,
Skipping upon the hills.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My beloved spake, and said unto me,
Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For, lo, the winter is past;
The rain is over and gone;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The fig-tree ripeneth her green figs,
And the vines are in blossom;
They give forth their fragrance.
Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock,
In the covert of the steep place,
Let me see thy countenance,
Let me hear thy voice;
For sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My beloved is mine, and I am his:
He feedeth his flock among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the day be cool, and the shadows flee away,
Turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a young hart
Upon the mountains of Bether.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By night on my bed
I sought him whom my soul loveth:
I sought him, but I found him not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, I will rise now, and go about the city;
In the streets and in the broad ways
I will seek him whom my soul loveth:
I sought him, but I found him not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchmen that go about the city found me;
To whom I said, Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It was but a little that I passed from them,
When I found him whom my soul loveth:
I held him, and would not let him go,
Until I had brought him into my mother’s house,
And into the chamber of her that conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
By the roes, or by the hinds of the field,
That ye stir not up, nor awake my love,
Until he please.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness
Like pillars of smoke,
Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
With all powders of the merchant?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They all handle the sword, and are expert in war:
Every man hath his sword upon his thigh,
Because of fear in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Solomon made himself a palanquin
Of the wood of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made the pillars thereof of silver,
The bottom thereof of gold, the seat of it of purple,
The midst thereof being paved with love,
From the daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold king Solomon,
With the crown wherewith his mother hath crowned him
In the day of his espousals,
And in the day of the gladness of his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair;
Thine eyes are as doves behind thy veil.
Thy hair is as a flock of goats,
That lie along the side of mount Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes that are newly shorn,
Which are come up from the washing,
Whereof every one hath twins,
And none is bereaved among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet,
And thy mouth is comely.
Thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate
Behind thy veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy neck is like the tower of David
Builded for an armory,
Whereon there hang a thousand bucklers,
All the shields of the mighty men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy two breasts are like two fawns
That are twins of a roe,
Which feed among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the day be cool, and the shadows flee away,
I will get me to the mountain of myrrh,
And to the hill of frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou art all fair, my love;
And there is no spot in thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come with me from Lebanon, my bride,
With me from Lebanon:
Look from the top of Amana,
From the top of Senir and Hermon,
From the lions’ dens,
From the mountains of the leopards.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How fair is thy love, my sister, my bride!
How much better is thy love than wine!
And the fragrance of thine oils than all manner of spices!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A garden shut up is my sister, my bride;
A spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy shoots are an orchard of pomegranates, with precious fruits;
Henna with spikenard plants,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Thou art a fountain of gardens,
A well of living waters,
And flowing streams from Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south;
Blow upon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out.
Let my beloved come into his garden,
And eat his precious fruits.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I was asleep, but my heart waked:
It is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying,
Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled;
For my head is filled with dew,
My locks with the drops of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have put off my garment; how shall I put it on?
I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door,
And my heart was moved for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I rose up to open to my beloved;
And my hands dropped with myrrh,
And my fingers with liquid myrrh,
Upon the handles of the bolt.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
If ye find my beloved,
That ye tell him, that I am sick from love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is thy beloved more than another beloved,
O thou fairest among women?
What is thy beloved more than another beloved,
That thou dost so adjure us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is white and ruddy,
The chiefest among ten thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His head is as the most fine gold;
His locks are bushy, and black as a raven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes are like doves beside the water-brooks,
Washed with milk, and fitly set.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His cheeks are as a bed of spices,
As banks of sweet herbs:
His lips are as lilies, dropping liquid myrrh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His hands are as rings of gold set with beryl:
His body is as ivory work overlaid with sapphires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold:
His aspect is like Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mouth is most sweet;
Yea, he is altogether lovely.
This is my beloved, and this is my friend,
O daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whither is thy beloved gone,
O thou fairest among women?
Whither hath thy beloved turned him,
That we may seek him with thee?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is gone down to his garden,
To the beds of spices,
To feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine:
He feedeth his flock among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou art fair, O my love, as Tirzah,
Comely as Jerusalem,
Terrible as an army with banners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn away thine eyes from me,
For they have overcome me.
Thy hair is as a flock of goats,
That lie along the side of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes,
Which are come up from the washing;
Whereof every one hath twins,
And none is bereaved among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate
Behind thy veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines,
And virgins without number.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Who is she that looketh forth as the morning,
Fair as the moon,
Clear as the sun,
Terrible as an army with banners?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went down into the garden of nuts,
To see the green plants of the valley,
To see whether the vine budded,
And the pomegranates were in flower.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before I was aware, my soul set me
Among the chariots of my princely people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return, return, O Shulammite;
Return, return, that we may look upon thee.
Why will ye look upon the Shulammite,
As upon the dance of Mahanaim?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful are thy feet in sandals, O prince’s daughter!
Thy rounded thighs are like jewels,
The work of the hands of a skilful workman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy body is like a round goblet,
Wherein no mingled wine is wanting:
Thy waist is like a heap of wheat
Set about with lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy two breasts are like two fawns
That are twins of a roe.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
How fair and how pleasant art thou,
O love, for delights!
speaker: Narrator

text:
This thy stature is like to a palm-tree,
And thy breasts to its clusters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, I will climb up into the palm-tree,
I will take hold of the branches thereof:
Let thy breasts be as clusters of the vine,
And the smell of thy breath like apples,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And thy mouth like the best wine,
That goeth down smoothly for my beloved,
Gliding through the lips of those that are asleep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my beloved’s;
And his desire is toward me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field;
Let us lodge in the villages.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us get up early to the vineyards;
Let us see whether the vine hath budded,
And its blossom is open,
And the pomegranates are in flower:
There will I give thee my love.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Oh that thou wert as my brother,
That sucked the breasts of my mother!
When I should find thee without, I would kiss thee;
Yea, and none would despise me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother’s house,
Who would instruct me;
I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine,
Of the juice of my pomegranate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left hand should be under my head,
And his right hand should embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
That ye stir not up, nor awake my love,
Until he please.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness,
Leaning upon her beloved?
Under the apple-tree I awakened thee:
There thy mother was in travail with thee,
There was she in travail that brought thee forth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
Neither can floods drown it:
If a man would give all the substance of his house for love,
He would utterly be contemned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have a little sister,
And she hath no breasts:
What shall we do for our sister
In the day when she shall be spoken for?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If she be a wall,
We will build upon her a turret of silver:
And if she be a door,
We will inclose her with boards of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a wall, and my breasts like the towers thereof
Then was I in his eyes as one that found peace.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My vineyard, which is mine, is before me:
Thou, O Solomon, shalt have the thousand,
And those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou that dwellest in the gardens,
The companions hearken for thy voice:
Cause me to hear it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make haste, my beloved,
And be thou like to a roe or to a young hart
Upon the mountains of spices.
speaker: Narrator
